item.title: Open Science Upgrade: Now Adding DOIs through Rogue Scholar
item.dc:creator: Adriano Rutz
item.description:
I have finally set up Rogue Scholar on my Quarto-based website! Every post should now automatically get a DOI.

This is something I have wanted to do for a long time, largely inspired by the tireless and consistent example set by Egon Willighagen (Willighagen 2024a, 2024b, 2025).

It was today’s post of (Fenner 2025) that finally motivated me to look into it again. That led me down a productive rabbit hole: first landing on (Csefalvay 2023)’s excellent guide, and then (Fruehwald 2025)’s clear write-up, both of which made the process of integrating Rogue Scholar into a Quarto-based site surprisingly smooth.

All the changes are documented in the following commit:

https://github.com/Adafede/adafede.github.io/commit/bc2dfe6f

If you’re using Quarto and care about attribution, long-term archiving, and DOIs and metadata, I highly recommend looking into Rogue Scholar.

References

Csefalvay, Chris von. 2023. “Auto-DOI for Quarto Posts via Rogue Scholar.” http://dx.doi.org/10.59350/5hxdg-fz574.
Fenner, Martin. 2025. “Rogue Scholar Citation Tracking Launches to Production.” http://dx.doi.org/10.53731/zyg15-qv911.
Fruehwald, Josef. 2025. “Setting up Rogue Scholar.” http://dx.doi.org/10.59350/3fp6d-e6z90.
Willighagen, Egon. 2024a. “GoatCounter, Rogue Scholar and More New Things.” http://dx.doi.org/10.59350/8x2f1-h6d21.
———. 2024b. “FAIR Blog-to-Blog Citations.” http://dx.doi.org/10.59350/er1mn-m5q69.
———. 2025. “Blog Updates.” http://dx.doi.org/10.59350/cf885-kee54.

Reuse

CC BY-SA 4.0
